TI Phonon assisted tunneling and peak-to-valley ratio in a magnetically
   confined quasi zero dimensional InGaAs/InAlAs resonant tunneling diode
SO JAPANESE JOURNAL OF APPLIED PHYSICS PART 1-REGULAR PAPERS SHORT NOTES &
   REVIEW PAPERS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 1996 International Conference on Solid State Devices and Materials (SSDM
   96)
CY AUG 26-29, 1996
CL YOKOHAMA, JAPAN
SP Japan Soc Appl Phys
DE resonant tunneling diode; zero dimensional electron gas; phonon
   relaxation
ID RELAXATION
AB We studied phonon-assisted tunneling and the peak-to-valley ratio (P/V ratio) of magnetically confined ''dot-like'' electron systems in an InGaAs/InAlAs triple barrier resonant tunneling diode. We observe phonon bottleneck, i.e., suppression of the nonresonant valley current and two mode narrow band GaAs- and AlAs-like longitudinal optical (LO)-phonon-assisted tunneling peaks. The P/V ratio increases remarkably with the magnetic confinement and has a maximum each time the energy separation of the confined states matches the GaAs-LO-phonon energy.
C1 ELECTROTECH LAB,TSUKUBA,IBARAKI 305,JAPAN.
   HOKKAIDO UNIV,FAC ENGN,SAPPORO,HOKKAIDO 060,JAPAN.
   UNIV TOKYO,INST SOLID STATE PHYS,TOKYO,JAPAN.

   Yamauchi, Y
   Yamamoto, A
TI Anomalous electrical characteristics of epitaxial InN films having a
   high electron concentration at very low temperature
SO JAPANESE JOURNAL OF APPLIED PHYSICS PART 2-LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE epitaxial InN; high electron concentration; sharp decrease of
   resistivity; magnetic field dependence; X-ray rocking curves; AFM
   observation
ID VAPOR-DEPOSITION GROWTH; INDIUM NITRIDE; SURFACE; SI
AB Epitaxial indium nitride films were grown by metalorganic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD) using trimethylindium (TMI) and ammonia (NH3). High electron concentrations of the order of 10(20) to 10(21) cm(-3) were obtained; which are considered to be due to nitrogen vacancies. The temperature dependence of the electrical properties of the epitaxial films were investigated. A sharp decrease of resistivity and an increase of mobility were observed below 4.2 K, and it was found that films with a lower electron concentration showed a sharper thermal slope of resistivity in the electron concentration range from 1 x 10(20) to 2 x 10(21) cm(-3). Moreover, a large magnetic field dependence of the differential resistance of the InN film was also seen at 1.4K. X-ray rocking curves and atomic force microscopy (AFM) images were measured for evaluation of the origin of these unusual electrical characteristics.

TI Angle dependent magnetoresistance oscillations of
   alpha-(BEDT-TTF)(2)KHg(SCN)(4) under high pressure
SO SYNTHETIC METALS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT International Conference on the Science and Technology of Synthetic
   Metals
CY JUL 28-AUG 02, 1996
CL SNOWBIRD, UT
SP Univ Utah, Elsevier Sci SA, Los Alamos Nat Lab, Monsanto, Off Naval Res, US Dept Energy, Bayer Corp, Taiwan United Microelec Corp, Uniax
DE transport measurements; conductivity; magnetotransport
ID ALPHA-(BEDT-TTF)2KHG(SCN)4; MAGNETOTRANSPORT
AB We measured angle dependent magnetoresistance oscillations of alpha-(BEDT-TTF)(2)KHg(SCN)(4) under high pressure to investigate relationship between the so-called anomalous state and the possible normal state above the critical pressure of about 5kbar. Above the critical pressure, we found two series of oscillations that ascertain the resurrection of the normal state. However, the anisotropy of magnetoresistance for magnetic fields rotated in the two-dimensional plane is difficult to explain in terms of the Fermi surface thus clarified.

TI Magnetic-field-induced phase transition and sliding motion of
   charge-density waves in eta-Mo4O11 crystals
SO PHYSICAL REVIEW B
LA English
DT Article
ID TRANSPORT-PROPERTIES; INSTABILITIES; OXIDES
AB Transverse magnetoresistance and Hall effect of the charge-density-wave (CDW) material eta-Mo4O11 have been measured at 4.2 K (second CDW state) by de and ac methods over the frequency range 50-500 kHz in pulsed magnetic fields up to 40 T. These quantities are both reversible and frequency independent for a low-field sweep up to near 10 T (=H-c), beyond which an appreciable frequency-dependent hysteresis effect appears. The Cole-Cole plots of the real versus imaginary parts of the magnetoresistance at high magnetic fields show a monodispersion. The magnetic-field dependence of the real part of the ac Hall resistivity shows interesting behaviors, peaking near H-c, followed by a decrease with H and a levelling off at high fields, while the imaginary Components are very small and less frequency dependent. Using a multicarrier model consisting of the remaining and nested electron and hole bands, we have performed computer simulations for these de and ac magnetotransport quantities, in satisfactory agreement with the observations. We have taken into account (1) the Zeeman effect for two types of the remaining hole and electron bands, (2) the CDW-gap narrowing of the nested electron and hole bands, (3) magnetic-field-induced CDW-to-normal phase transition in part of these nested bands, and (4) the magnetic-field-induced ''CDW oscillation'' around some mean position of the CDW condensates (or thermal excitation of the. CDW phasons over a pinning potential), according to the existing cow model.

TI Detection of morphine in ppb range by using SPR
   (surface-plasmon-resonance) immunosensor
SO CHEMISTRY LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
AB Highly sensitive detection of morphine (MO) in ppb range was realized by using an immunosensor based on surfaceplasmon-resonance (SPR) phenomena. The addition of MO into the antibody solution was found to reduce the incident angle shift of the SPR sensor system sharply because of the inhibition effect of MO. Based on this inhibiting principle, the present sensor could detect MO very sensitively in the concentration range of 0.1 - 10 ng/cm(3) (ppb).
